instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent
threads.message: have a 00165 that presents no prior liquid damage or technical work that works and posts intermittently. when it posts, vcore is present. when it doesn't, vcore and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> are not present, yet the fan spins (not fast) for about 30 seconds. However, when it does post, the fan goes to full (obviously with the tp disconnected) and runs ok.  Ideas? (when it doesn't post, 3v42, g3h are all present.)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent
threads.message:
When doesn't post, can you check if any signal pulses?
Like <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 42875"]When doesn't post, can you check if any signal pulses?
Like <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>...[/QUOTE]

They all run fine at first, but when it goes to non post, it drops from 3.3v (<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> for instance), to .58 v then to 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is present on these 30s when fan still spins?
If it really spins, because <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is needed...
"when it doesn't, vcore and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> are not present"

BTW, don't quote an entire post from few cm above...
